posts.author: Orion
posts.content:
The Arcane Dwarven Dreadlord



Source: https://www.pinterest.com.au/pin/421579215109475536/

Lore:
August General Bulin Buntaiden, the first born son of the Great Dwarven Lord Buntaiden of Kol Tarihr and one of the city's greatest, brightest and most ambitious generals in history, has left his mountain undercity in search of power eternal to defeat the mortal enemies of his people, the denizens of the Underdark. 

His home undercity beset on all sides by horrifying monstrosities, Bulin seeks power beyond that of usual mortals, and to return to deliver terrible devastation to his enemies, to save Kol Tarihr and maintain the honor of his house Buntaiden. 

He is willing to pay any price, even the price of his own mortality to obtain absolute arcane power to ensure his people's safety... 

...and in the deep of the night he hears the whispers of his fallen comrades and soldiers, the fallen defenders of Kol Tarihr, offering him the power of their souls in exchange for vengeance... 

...for in him they see Kol Tarihr's salvation...

...and without hesitation he is prepared to accept...

...for he believes enduring this pain this is his place in life...

...the heavy burden of responsibility...

...his duty to his fallen comrades, many of whom loyally followed his orders to their death...

...that the ends justifies the means...

...and he accepts the mantle of becoming the city's immortal guardian... 

...for eternity...

Cool features:

- AB 40, 4 attacks per round with mundane greatsword, AC 31 with mundane plate
- Base Strength 30, base Devastating Critical DC 40 (Devastating Critical obtained at level 30)
- Improved Knockdown and Improved Disarm (or Improved Expertise, depending on your playstyle)

- Up to level 9 wizard spells plus Epic Warding, Still spell, Extended spell and Empower spell (or Craft Wand)
- Time Stop / Mord or Time Stop / Devastating Critical Combo, up to three Time Stop spells per day

- Over 400 natural hp 
- Critical hit immunity, Sneak attack immunity, Stun/Paralysis/Hold immunity
- +11 to saves against spells

- Over 250 skill points to spend to max discipline, concentration, near max spellcraft, 20 crossclassed ranks in tumble, and others as desired

- No exp penalties

Downsides:

- dispellable buffs (except EW), difficulties with spell penetration, 
- due to base attribute modifier of 4 will want to focus on either no save spell casting or target weak saves of opponents

Other F/W/PM builds:

There are 12 F/W/PM builds I can find in the archives. From which the most similar builds are Grizzled_Dwarflord's Deathless Pariah, Mithdradates's Soldier of Death and Deadmoney9951's Undead Spellsword. 

Soldier of Death has Devastating Critical but only up to level 6 wizard spells. 

Deathless Pariah and Undead Spellsword get level 9 wizard spells, but don't get Devastating Critical because they focus on getting Automatic Still Spell III (which I feel uncomfortable with, with only 10-18 caster levels and an attribute modifier of 4-5). Undead Spellsword has 3 attacks per round. 

So this should be a unique contribution as far as I'm aware. 

Environment:
I've assumed Time Stop and Mords scrolls are easily accessible in the environment you are playing in. 

If they aren't then swap the Wizard Bonus Feats (Great Intelligence and Empower Spell) around so that Great Intelligence is taken at Character Level 21 rather than Character Level 38. That way both spells can be taken as free spells at Wizard Level ups.

If Devastating Critical is disabled or nerfed in your environment, Overwhelming Critical and Devastating Critical can be swapped for either Two Great Strengths (for base Str 32 and base AB 41) or Epic Weapon Specialisation and Armor Skin (for additional +4 damage per hit and +2AC).

Craft wand is very attractive in persistent worlds (where gold and exp loss from crafting magic is not an issue). It should be considered over Empower Spell, as given buffs are dispellable, a wand (ie an improved invisibility wand) most of them to be recast.

Acknowledgements:
Appreciate Valerfor's who suggested about 6 or so improvements to the build which I have incorporated
Appreciate Mick Dagger's suggestion to include at least one rank in Disable Trap to ensure any traps that have been set can be retrieved.
Appreciate stephenratcliffe809's suggestions on Craft Wand and Improved Expertise

Quick q on this please Orion - why both Imp KD and Imp Disarm, since they're both Discipline checks?

Wouldn't Expertise / Imp Expertise instead of Disarm give a more flexible build?

posts.author: Orion
posts.content:
Expertise / Improved Expertise is a good feat in the early levels to reduce damage dealt to you, and tank damage for parties.

However later on I thought it would become irrelevant with Pale Master granting  up to +10AC, crit immunity, sneak immunity, stun/hold/paralysis immunity, undispellable epic warding and level 9 wizard buffs (admittedly dispellable buffs like improved invisibility for 50% concealment,  etc). This Fighter / Pale Master certainly can tank for sure, and expertise I thought would just be overkill. Even a sword and shield is overkill, he really needs a large two handed weapon to make the most of all of these defensive capabilities he gets from PM. I could have even made a variant of this guy to have 500 hp at the cost of 1AB, but I valued that 1AB more than the 80hp, its a 5% increased chance to hit and 5% increased chance to crit on threat rolls.

Improved Disarm I just liked it in the tool kit better than Expertise for a large weapon wielder:
- a situational AB buff against small (+4 -ie +20% chance to hit/crit) or tiny (+8 - ie +40% chance to hit/crit) weapon wielders, resisting the disarm attempt with discipline could be potentially beneficial to you. 
- there are no penalties against medium weapon wielders, so any shield using opponent you can spam improved disarm until they lose their weapon. 
- any disarmed non-monk opponents you can just wear a +1 soak 10 or 15 damage item, or a greater brawler belt (bludgeoning 20/-) and they will essentially do very little damage to you
- only immunities to disarm are unarmed monks and creature weapons, unlike knockdown/improved knockdown

If you want the extra AC in the early game to tank for your party you can also always go one handed and tower shield temporarily, but in the mid and late game that big two handed weapon is very attractive

Edit: I also forgot to mention a disarmed non-monk non creature weapon non-glove/bracer wearing opponents, if they are forced to fight you with their fists, will grant you free attacks of opportunity / round, which appear to be full AB when I check the combat log

posts.author: Stagmeister
posts.content:
Hi Stephen, really pleased you're enjoying Orion's build (apart from the buff stripping, obviously - though that just sounds wrong somehow...).

The point of this post, though, is to offer a cautionary note about Great Cleave. It can be very useful, certainly. but if you're headed for a big nasty mage protected by a mob and you can't skip round to get to the focus of your ire, you can easily find yourself screwed, because Great Cleave kicks in and means you have to fight the mob first, whether you want to or not. And weirdly, the better you are at one-hit killing, the easier it is to get trapped in a Great Cleave cycle when mobbed. I'd like to see it as a selected option, rather than an automatic one - and you won't often hear that from me.

Just a word of warning...

posts.author: Orion
posts.content:
Glad you've gotten through the hardest part of the build!

Playing essentially a pure fighter as a soloist in WoG is extremely challenging, and Kudos to you!

Regarding the buffs getting stripped - as far as I can gather its the price of being a proper spellsword (ie a non-cleric).

Even the best non-cleric spellsword builds with undispellability (such as Valerfor Abjurant Champion + Mick Dagger's variant on the build) seem to get undispellability of buffs late (for example Abjurant Champion is like at level 37-39 ish) - the combat class levels tend to be preferred pre-epic so the AB doesn't suffer later on. At least the Abjurant Champion gets a degree of resistance to dispelling with the increased caster level progression which Pale Master doesn't provide (but provides a lot of other great defensive capabilities in exchange).

You probably know all this stuff given how fast you've progressed but I've put it out there just in case!

Valerfor taught me sometimes its good to bait out the dispel abilities from casters. One idea was a mildly buffed (ie resistance) heroic badger summon for example. Sometimes I've cast grease spells around the area with my casters as well to do this.

Scribing unused spells before resting could be handy too, in a persistent world. 

At level 21 you should have access to level 4 wizard spells by now! 

A level 4 wizard spell such as improved invisibility is going to be very handy for a greatsword wielding 22 strength killer dwarf, and a few spare scrolls are going to be handy in combat if it gets dispelled.

Looking forward to when you have crit/sneak immunity, devastating critical with a Keen edged greatsword and epic warding!
